channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Can Bayern make Euro history?
item.description: Defending champions Bayern Munich will play Manchester United in the quarterfinals of the European Champions League.

item.title: Adam Scott: Beware the sick golfer
item.description: There's an old saying in golf -- "beware the injured golfer."

item.title: Curtain rises on MotoGP season
item.description: As motorcycle racing's elite gather for the night-time curtain raiser at Qatar's floodlit Losail circuit, CNN looks ahead to the new season.

item.title: F1: Red Bull appeals disqualification
item.description: Red Bull has appealed Daniel Ricciardo's disqualification from last weekend's Australian Grand Prix, the first round of the Formula One season.

item.title: Venus on Sjogren's syndrome fight
item.description: Everyone has had one of those mornings -- you wake up groggy, can't face going to work, dive back under the covers and go back to sleep.

item.title: How families of Flight 370 can cope
item.description: It is agony for the relatives of the 239 people on board Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which set out from Kuala Lumpur heading to Beijing on the night of March 8. After more than a week, the plane is still missing. With new clues spawning new theories every day, authorities are searching a huge area of nearly 3 million square miles of the Indian Ocean.

item.title: The science of happiness
item.description: Kortni Alston says the study of happiness has become a serious pursuit, with references to happiness showing up in music, movies, books, clothing and even the grocery store

item.title: At TED, miracles and fears
item.description: The 30th anniversary of TED put a spotlight on the amazing potential of technology and its dangers

item.title: Sanctions: EU should leave trade alone
item.description: With a breezy sweep of his pen President Vladimir Putin wrote a new chapter into Crimea's turbulent history, committing the region to a future returned to Russian domain.

item.title: Flight 370: Hunt for new leads proves fruitless
item.description: A British newspaper says it has a transcript of communications from the cockpit of the missing airliner as a second day of searching for debris ends without success.

item.title: Purported transcript: 'Coms normal'
item.description: No struggle. No panic. No clues.

item.title: Race to detect 370 beacon
item.description: Somewhere in the vast Indian Ocean, a tiny aluminum cylinder may be emitting a steady ping that is taking on the cadence of a slowly failing clock.

item.title: Looking for debris in sea of garbage
item.description: Two weeks after Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappeared, one thing has been made clear: the ocean is full of garbage, literally.

item.title: Malaysians defend response
item.description: What do Malaysians think about the disappearance of Flight 370, and criticism of their government's reaction?

item.title: Thai election declared invalid
item.description: Thailand's constitutional court has declared the country's February 2 general election invalid as it breached a law requiring that the polling process be completed on the same day nationwide.

item.title: Journalist among dead in Kabul
item.description: A staff reporter for the Agence France-Presse news agency, his wife and two of his three children were among nine civilians killed in an attack on a hotel in the Afghan capital, the news agency said Friday.

item.title: Wave of violence targets Iraq's Sunnis
item.description: A wave of violence swept across Iraq on Friday, resulting in at least 38 deaths, police said. Most of the casualties occurred in Sunni towns and cities, according to police in Baquba, Ramadi, Mosul, Samarra, Kirkuk and Tikrit.

item.title: 6.3 quake reported in Indian Ocean
item.description: A 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck in the sea off India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands on Friday evening -- a week after a weaker quake shook the area, the India Meteorological Department said.

item.title: Turkey outrage at Twitter 'eradication'
item.description: Hours after Turkey's prime minister vowed to "eradicate" Twitter, Turkish Internet users began to experience widespread disruptions Thursday while trying to access the popular social networking website.

item.title: Twitter users dodge Erdogan's ban
item.description: CNN Turk anchor Cuneyt Ozdemir explains why Turkey's PM Tayyip Erdogan has vowed to 'eradicate' Twitter.

item.title: Billionaire buys Viber for $900M
item.description: Samuel Burke talks with Japanese billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani about his recent purchase of instant messaging app Viber.

item.title: Michelle Obama arrives in China
item.description: First lady Michelle Obama is in China for an official visit to expand Sino-American relations, but she will refrain from talking about political differences.

item.title: Pistorius selling home for legal costs
item.description: Oscar Pistorius -- the standout athlete now on trial for murder for the death of his girlfriend -- plans to sell his Pretoria home "to raise the necessary funds to cover his increasing legal costs," a statement on his website said Thursday.

item.title: Anti-gay pastor Fred Phelps dies
item.description: Fred Phelps -- the founding pastor of a Kansas church known for its virulently anti-gay protests at public events, including military funerals -- has died, the church said Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine signs EU trade pact
item.description: EU leaders plan to sign a political association agreement with Ukraine on Friday, demonstrating the bloc's solidarity with the nation in the face of the annexation of its Crimea region by Russia.

item.title: Aides from Putin's inner circle targeted
item.description: European Union leaders agreed to earmark 12 more individuals for visa restrictions and asset freezes in the second stage of their four-step plan to prompt Russia to renege on its annexation of Crimea.

item.title: Ukraine beefing up defenses
item.description: Ukraine is recruiting tens of thousands of troops, preparing to defend itself. CNN's Ivan Watson reports.

item.title: Clockwork boy writes poems
item.description: Charles Penniman first met the clockwork boy at the age of 6, now 85 he is still fascinated by the mysterious automata.

item.title: 'Frozen' Falls tricks tourists
item.description: Tourists visiting Niagara Falls were disappointed to find the rapids were not completely frozen. WGRZ reports.

item.title: Russians calling London home
item.description: Russian immigrants are now a thoroughly integrated part of the UK economy. CNN's Isa Soares reports.

item.title: Anti-Barbie doll
item.description: Doll with "real" proportions gets crowd-funded in 24 hours. WTAE's Wendy Bell reports.

item.title: Tourist to time traveler
item.description: It's an app that uses your phone as a window to historical London. Adam Dunnakey takes a look.

item.title: Octopus snatches camera
item.description: Scuba divers were taking pictures of an octopus when it decided to grab hold of the camera.

item.title: Need to hide from the world?
item.description: Shack up in style with 13 most remarkable miniature hideaways.

item.title: Priest saves man from death row
item.description: Father Neil Kookoothe used his unusual skill set and found undisclosed evidence that saved a man from the death chamber. It is time for America to force prosecutors to open their files?

item.title: Pakistan sheltered Bin Laden? 'Prove it'
item.description: Peter Bergen says a New York Times reporter makes the explosive claim that Pakistan new Bin Laden was hiding in Abbottabad. That would be big news--but it's not true

item.title: How Westgate attack changed lives
item.description: To mark six months since the attack on Nairobi's Westgate mall, CNN asked how Kenyans have moved on with their lives. Using the our hashtag #Westgate6Months, here's what you said.

item.title: How many? You can smell 1 trillion scents
item.description: Our noses are incredibly sensitive -- and a new study provides evidence of just how amazing our sniffers are.

item.title: Lady Gaga spews forth: This is no act
item.description: After staging a "vomit as art" performance and facing lackluster sales for her latest album, Lady Gaga is ready to speak her piece.

item.title: Cloak app to avoid awkward encounters
item.description: After moving to New York, Brian Moore could not stop running into his ex-girlfriend. There were four awkward and unplanned encounters in six months, to be exact.

item.title: Japan: Land of the rising scrum?
item.description: Spawned by university professors and dominated by big corporations, rugby in Japan is certainly different -- but it is also on the rise ahead of this week's Tokyo Sevens.

item.title: 8 irresistible indoor hotel pools
item.description: When it comes to hotel pools, the indoor variety has long played second fiddle to their outdoor -- often rooftop -- counterparts. But these days, striking d√©cor, luxury amenities and stunning settings mean many indoor swimming holes can now challenge even the most glamorous of outdoor pools.

item.title: Venezuela blames woman for protests
item.description: The Venezuelan government is blaming weeks of violent clashes on one woman, opposition lawmaker Maria Corina Machado.

item.title: Inside guide to rugby sevens
item.description: Pace, power and partying -- is this the ultimate sporting tour?

item.title: Who can challenge bike wonder kid?
item.description: New riders. Fresh drama. More controversy. Find out all you need to know here.

item.title: New Rwanda: 'Death Then, Life Now'
item.description: A new exhibition showcases insightful snapshots of daily life in today's Rwanda as seen through the eyes of local photographers.

item.title: Michelle Obama's pingpong diplomacy
item.description: More than 40 years after pingpong diplomacy led to a thaw in Sino-American relations, it was on display again -- in rudimentary form -- as Michelle Obama visited a Beijing high school during her family's first full day of a visit to China.

item.title: World's hottest new surf spot?
item.description: Morocco is famous for its historic cities and rugged landscape. But it's becoming known as a surfer's paradise.

item.title: Drug violence creates 'chop-up houses'
item.description: Cartel turf wars are leaving a trail of death and terror in a Colombian port, activists say.

item.title: Seoul unveils 'spaceship' landmark
item.description: A city that never sleeps opens the doors to its biggest night attraction yet.

item.title: Africa's last polar bear is heartbroken
item.description: Africa's last polar bear spends his days grieving his longtime companion at a zoo in Johannesburg, a far cry from his Arctic habitat.

item.title: China adds 'chili pepper' to graft fight
item.description: Xi Jinping's anti-corruption drive heats up as military officials come under growing scrutiny.

item.title: Million-dollar egg nearly scrap metal
item.description: A jumble find destined for sale to metal dealers turns out to be a Faberge egg -- worth millions.

item.title: World's happiest countries are ...
item.description: There must be something in the water of these 10 countries.

item.title: U.S. baseball goes down under
item.description: The Sydney Cricket ground prepares for a new moment of history as it swaps stumps and bails for a home plate.

item.title: FIFA reformer wants Qatar 2022 rerun
item.description: Leading former FIFA insider Alexandra Wrage is calling for a new vote over the selection of the 2022 World Cup hosts given the ongoing controversy surrounding the decision to award Qatar the event.

item.title: Kids who don't cry: Disorder discovered
item.description: Identifying new genetic mutations has gotten easier and cheaper. But geneticists often struggle to find patients who share these rare DNA quirks.

item.title: Happy Scandinavians
item.description: Becky Anderson talks to Ludvig Lindstrom and Mark Williamson about the UN's International Day of Happiness

item.title: Flight 370: Relatives hope for miracle
item.description: Families of those on Flight 370 hang onto hope that the missing plane remains intake somewhere with the passengers alive.

item.title: Why sanctions will hurt all sides
item.description: With Europe's economy on the rebound and Russia's on the wane, there's a lot at stake.

item.title: Venus rises from under the covers
item.description: Everyone has had one of those mornings -- you wake up groggy, can't face going to work, dive back under the covers and go back to sleep. Tennis star Venus Williams knows exactly how that feels -- but she is beating the autoimmune disease that derailed her career.

item.title: If debris is found, what happens next?
item.description: If this is 'it,' the wreckage of MH 370 that departed Kuala Lumpur on March 8, what's next? The race will be on to get to it.

item.title: Animal photos that break your heart
item.description: Former champion jockey Richard Dunwoody has gone from riding winners to highlighting the plight of working animals in his second career as a photographer.

item.title: The deadly day that changed Kiev
item.description: A month on, CNN's Todd Baxter reflects on the deadliest day of the Kiev protests.

item.title: Debris sighting stirs families' emotions
item.description: The search for debris that could belong to missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 evokes different emotions for relatives of the passengers.

item.title: What does Vladimir Putin want next?
item.description: Is Russia's leader an opportunist, seizing chances to poke the West in the eye, or a clever strategist?

item.title: Why Putin's wrong to blame my great-grandfather
item.description: The Russian president claims Crimea was lost by Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev -- but Stalin was the real villain, says his descendant.

item.title: Who are the missing passengers?
item.description: The youngest is 2, the oldest 76. The missing flight also carried a stunt man and an artist, pilgrims and commuters. CNN profiles those aboard the stricken flight.

item.title: Probe throws up more questions
item.description: Investigators sift through more theories about the missing airliner -- including a pilot's phone call and battery fire risk. But time is running out. CNN explores what we know.

item.title: Pilots return disappointed
item.description: Go inside the Australian Air Force Base Pearce as pilots return from day two of searching for missing Flight 370.

item.title: Will plane search be Asia's wake-up call?
item.description: In 2003, the SARS virus epidemic was a wake-up call for Asia, forcing China to increase transparency, fostering closer regional cooperation and bringing human security issues to the fore. The disappearance of MH370 will have a similar transformative effect on regional security, but it will take a different form.

item.title: Hotel attack
item.description: A staff reporter for the Agence France-Presse news agency, his wife and two of his three children were among nine civilians killed in an attack on a hotel in the Afghan capital, the news agency said Friday.

item.title: Happiest countries
item.description: There must be something in the water of these 10 countries.

item.title: Faberge egg
item.description: A jumble find destined for sale to metal dealers turns out to be a Faberge egg -- worth millions.

item.title: Seoul 'spaceship'
item.description: A city that never sleeps opens the doors to its biggest night attraction yet.

item.title: China's iconic dress
item.description: It's perhaps the most iconic scene in the most iconic Hong Kong movie of all time.

item.title: Buildings with a hollow middle
item.description: From a giant ice cube to a building shaped like a coin, it seems architects are increasingly drawn to buildings you can see straight through.

item.title: Dark drama of Venice Carnival
item.description: Every spring Halloween meets haute couture at the Carnival of Venice.

item.title: Female biker gangs of Marrakech
item.description: The word "motorcycle" often conjures up images of tattooed men wearing black leather jackets. Not so in Marrakech. The city's thriving bike culture includes plenty of women. With their polka dot veils and heart-shaped sunglasses, they're steering motorcycle fashion in their own direction.

item.title: How Louis Vuitton fortune was built
item.description: On a breezy spring day in 1835, a 13-year-old boy from the Jura region of eastern France set out for the glittering metropolis of Paris to seek his fortune.

item.title: Enter into Congo's cult of elegance
item.description: Known as "Sapeurs," these dapper dressers are part of a Congolese subculture devoted to the cult of style.

item.title: Karl Lagerfeld on trends
item.description: Myleene Klass talks with fashion designer Karl Lagerfeld about his latest fashion style.

item.title: A one of a kind friendship
item.description: A two-legged chihuahua and a fluffy chicken have become best friends.

item.title: World's most extraordinary hotels
item.description: They're not always the most popular or conventional hotels. And that's exactly what Lonely Planet's going for with its inaugural picks for the world's best accommodations.

item.title: Students storm Taiwan Legislature
item.description: Hundreds of students remained barricaded in Taiwan's Legislature early Wednesday in protest of the ruling party's push for a trade pact with China, which demonstrators claim will hurt the island.

item.title: For Ukrainians, 'it's hard to not be concerned'
item.description: Some people believed that one of the most democratic ways out of the conflict between Russia and Ukraine was to let people of Crimea decide their fates for themselves through a referendum. But there were a few serious flaws with that "democratic" approach.

item.title: A priest reflects on Pope Francis
item.description: A few days ago, I was coming home from school with a Polish priest. As we walked, he blurted out, "The smell of spring!"

item.title: HK's parody Communist rally
item.description: Just call it the Fake Leap Forward.

item.title: 'Locust' shopper fears in HK
item.description: In the neon canyons of Hong Kong's Tsim Tsa Tsui -- Hong Kong's main urban shopping precinct -- the proliferation of one type of shop has cropped up along its bustling streets in recent years.

item.title: Dozens stabbed in China
item.description: Officials say a separatist group from Xinjiang carried out a mass attack at a rail station.

item.title: Weibo users flee to WeChat?
item.description: Users are ditching Weibo for WeChat as tightened government oversight takes its toll.

item.title: Beijing smog levels drop
item.description: Strong winds have helped temporarily clear the air over Beijing and residents could not be happier.

item.title: School builds air dome
item.description: A Beijing school constructs two domes to allow students to play outside and avoid smog.

item.title: Obama, Dalai Lama meet
item.description: President Barack Obama met on Friday with the Dalai Lama, the Tibetan spiritual leader, despite China's appeal not to do so.

item.title: China gets tough with media
item.description: On the Reporters Without Borders map of global press freedom, China appears as one big black spot.

item.title: 'House of Cards' surprise hit
item.description: Like countless Americans, I recently watched the entire second season of hit political drama "House of Cards" in one weekend after U.S. video streaming site Netflix released all 13 nearly hour-long episodes.

item.title: Cemetery business booms
item.description: Like many companies in China, Fu Shou Yuan uses celebrities to attract clients. Except, in this case, they're dead.

item.title: 'Baby hatches' rolled out
item.description: The number of China's so-called "baby hatches" -- places where mothers can leave newborn babies anonymously -- is set to increase as the government tries to protect more of the country's abandoned infants.
